<ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan data of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in 1.7<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup> mol dm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> DMF solution at 532 nm with <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> being 8.2<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>W m<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>: (a) collected under the open aperture configuration showing NLO absorption; (b) obtained by dividing the normalized <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan data obtained under closed aperture configuration by the normalized <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan data in (a) (self-focusing effect). The solid curves are the theoretical fit based on Eqs. <ce:cross-refs refid="FD1 FD2 FD3 FD4 FD5">(1)–(5)</ce:cross-refs>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

elements.clean_text: Fig. 6   Z-scan data of polymer 1 in 1.7×10-4 mol dm-3 DMF solution at 532 nm with I 0 being 8.2×1012W m-2: (a) collected under the open aperture configuration showing NLO absorption; (b) obtained by dividing the normalized Z-scan data obtained under closed aperture configuration by the normalized Z-scan data in (a) (self-focusing effect). The solid curves are the theoretical fit based on Eqs. (1)-(5).

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two novel Co(II) coordination polymers {[Co(H2O)2(CH3OH)2(4-bpfp)](NO3)2} n  1 (4-bpfp=N,N '-bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine) and [Co(NCS)2(CH3OH)2(3-bpfp)] n  2 (3-bpfp=N,N '-bis(3-pyridylformyl)piperazine) have been synthesized and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Both the polymers consist of one-dimensional chains constructed by bridging bpfp ligands and Co(II) ions. The existence of O⋯H-O hydrogen bond in 1 and S⋯H-O hydrogen bond in 2 play important roles in creating interesting supramolecular structures. Their third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties in DMF solution have been studied by Z-scan technique. The results reveal that polymers 1 and 2 exhibit strong NLO absorption effects (α 2=9.00×10-11 m W-1 for 1; 1.41×10-10 m W-1 for 2) and self-focusing performance (n 2=3.24×10-16 esu for 1; 3.05×10-16 esu for 2) in DMF solutions. The corresponding effective NLO susceptibilities χ (3) values are 3.08×10-12 esu (1) and 4.70×10-12 esu (2). All of the values are comparable to those of the reported good NLO materials. Additionally, the TG-DTA results of the two polymers are in agreement with the crystal structures.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past decades, the research of transition metal coordination polymers has been an attractive area because of their fantastic structures and potential applications. In this realm, Co-containing polymers are of topical interest mostly due to their diverse structures . A large of number of Co(II) coordination polymers have been reported up to now. Examples of 1D polymers include straight chain [Co(4,4'-bpy)(H2O)4](ClO4)2 ⋅(4,4'-bpy)2 ⋅2H2O , zigzag chain [CoCl2(PPz)] n  (PPz=piperazine) , ladder-like [Co(4,4'-bipy)1.5(NO3)2]⋅guest (guest=MeCH or CHCl3) , trans-1D chain [Co(4,4'-bipy)(SO4)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O and [Co(4,4'-bipy)(Cl)2(DMSO)2] . 2D polymers include grid [Co(NCS)2(4,4'-bipy)2]2 ⋅(CH3CH2)2O , [CoBr2(btd)] n  and [CoCl2(btd)] n , (btd=2,1,3-benzothiadiazole) , sheet-like [Co(L)2(NCS)2] (L=Pyrimidine or Pyrazine) , herringbone {[Co2(NO3)4(4,4'-azpy)3]⋅CH2Cl2} n  (4,4'-azpy=trans-4,4'-azobis(pyridine)) , and 3D chiral networks include [Co(oda)(H2O)⋅H2O] n  (H2oda=oxydiacetic acid) , and so on.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">While, we are not only interested in the design and preparation of Co-polymers with diversified structures, but also interested in investigating their potential properties, especially their nonlinear optical (NLO) properties. Traditionally, NLO properties' research focuses on inorganic oxides, semiconductors, cluster compounds, conjugated polymers and discrete organic molecules , but seldom touches transition metal coordination polymers. In recent years, researchers have initiated the investigation on the third-order NLO properties of coordination polymers, and have found many of them exhibit strong NLO absorption, self-focusing or self-defocussing behaviors . Lately, our group reported the third-order NLO studies for M-bpfp (M=Hg(II), Cd(II), Mn(II) or Zn(II), bpfp=<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bis(3-pyridylformyl)piperazine) coordination polymers , Cd(II), Mn(II) and Zn(II) polymers of which show strong NLO absorptive and refractive effects. Thus, as an extension to our previous work, we synthesize two novel 1D chain Co(II)-bpfp coordination polymers: {[Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpfp)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Both <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine (4-bpfp) and <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bis(3-pyridylformyl)piperazine (3-bpfp) were prepared according to the appropriate literature procedure . Other chemicals were of A.R. Grade and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Fourier Nicolet FT-170SX spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets in the 400–4000 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region. Electronic spectra were taken on a Hitachi U-3410 spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen) were carried out on a Carlo–Erba 1106 Elemental Analyzer. The thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TGA-DTA) were performed using PERKIN–ELMER TGA7 and DTA7 analyzers in air from 25 to 1100 °C using a 10 °C/min heating rate.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General

Both N,N '-bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine (4-bpfp) and N,N '-bis(3-pyridylformyl)piperazine (3-bpfp) were prepared according to the appropriate literature procedure . Other chemicals were of A.R. Grade and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Fourier Nicolet FT-170SX spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. Electronic spectra were taken on a Hitachi U-3410 spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen) were carried out on a Carlo-Erba 1106 Elemental Analyzer. The thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TGA-DTA) were performed using PERKIN-ELMER TGA7 and DTA7 analyzers in air from 25 to 1100 °C using a 10 °C/min heating rate.

elements.clean_text:
Preparation of polymer {[Co(H2O)2(CH3OH)2(4-bpfp)](NO3)2} n  (1)

A clear methanol solution (5 ml) of 4-bpfp (59.2 mg, 0.20 mmol) was dropwise added into a methanol solution (3 ml) of Co(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) at room temperature. The vial was subjected to shaking about 30 min resulting in a pale red solution. On standing for three weeks, pale red crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained in 46% yield. Anal. Calc. for C20H28N4O12Co: C, 33.34; H, 4.87; N, 12.50%; Found: C, 33.52; H, 4.77; N, 12.83%. IR (KBr) ν(cm-1): 3363s, 1621s, 1492m, 1468m, 1384s, 1283m, 1162w, 1006m, 831w, 744w, 708w.

elements.clean_text:
Preparation of polymer [Co(NCS)2(CH3OH)2(3-bpfp)] n  (2)

At room temperature, a clear methanol solution (4 ml) of 3-bpfp (59.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) was slowly added into a methanol solution (2 ml) of Co(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) with continuous stirring. Then a methanol solution (2 ml) of KSCN (19.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) was dropwise added into above mixture while stirring and resulted in a clear red solution. In the next day, pale red crystals (yield: 43%) were deposited from the solution. Anal. Calc. for C20H22CoN6O4S2: C, 39.93; H, 4.55; N, 14.71; Found: C, 39.47; H, 4.50; N, 14.78%. IR (KBr) ν(cm-1): 3290m, 2089s, 1634s, 1600m, 1460w, 1437s, 1274m, 1159w, 1008s, 823w, 735m, 709w.

elements.clean_text:
and refinement of the structures

Both measurements were made on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector using graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). All the data were collected at the temperature of 18±1 °C using the ω-2θ scan technique and corrected for Lorenz-polarization effects. A correction for secondary extinction was applied. The two structures were solved by direct methods and expanded using Fourier techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were included but not refined. All calculations were performed using SHELXL-97 Program . Crystal data and experimental details for polymers 1 and 2 are shown in  . Selected bond lengths and bond angles of 1 and 2 are listed in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>NLO measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A dilute DMF solution for polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (1.7<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup> mol dm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>) or <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (1.9<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup> mol dm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>) was placed in a 1-mm quartz cuvette for NLO measurement. Their NLO properties were measured as described in the literature , and were evaluated by the <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan technique with a pulse width of 8 ns at 532 nm and 2-Hz repetition rate.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
NLO measurements

A dilute DMF solution for polymer 1 (1.7×10-4 mol dm-3) or 2 (1.9×10-4 mol dm-3) was placed in a 1-mm quartz cuvette for NLO measurement. Their NLO properties were measured as described in the literature , and were evaluated by the Z-scan technique with a pulse width of 8 ns at 532 nm and 2-Hz repetition rate.

Results and discussion

Syntheses and spectroscopic characterization

The reaction pathways of polymers 1 and 2 are shown in  . It should be pointed out that the proper molar ratio of Co(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O and bpfp is an effective route for preparation of good single crystals. The single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction can be obtained from reaction of Co(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O and bpfp in the molar ratio of 1:2 instead of 1:1.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Structural description</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Crystal structure of {[Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpfp)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of 1D [Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpfp)] chains and lattice nitrate anions. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>, each cobalt atom is six-coordinated and bonds to four equatorial oxygen atoms in an approximately square-plane fashion and two axial pyridyl nitrogen atoms in a linear manner. The 4-bpfp ligands adopt <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-configuration. The bond length of Co–O<ce:inf loc="post">H2O</ce:inf> is 2.090(4) Å, which is almost equal to that of Co–O<ce:inf loc="post">CH3OH</ce:inf> (2.093(3) Å), but is shorter than that of Co–N<ce:inf loc="post">bpfp</ce:inf> (2.176(3) Å). This gives raise to an elongated octahedral coordination sphere. Additionally, the bond angles of N(3)–Co(1)–O(2), N(3)–Co(1)–N(1) and O(2)–Co(1)–N(1) are 89.96(17), 91.56(15) and 92.23(14)°, respectively, further indicate slight distortion of the octahedron.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural description

Crystal structure of {[Co(H2O)2(CH3OH)2(4-bpfp)](NO3)2} n  (1)

Polymer 1 consists of 1D [Co(H2O)2(CH3OH)2(4-bpfp)] chains and lattice nitrate anions. As shown in  , each cobalt atom is six-coordinated and bonds to four equatorial oxygen atoms in an approximately square-plane fashion and two axial pyridyl nitrogen atoms in a linear manner. The 4-bpfp ligands adopt trans-configuration. The bond length of Co-OH2O is 2.090(4) Å, which is almost equal to that of Co-OCH3OH (2.093(3) Å), but is shorter than that of Co-Nbpfp (2.176(3) Å). This gives raise to an elongated octahedral coordination sphere. Additionally, the bond angles of N(3)-Co(1)-O(2), N(3)-Co(1)-N(1) and O(2)-Co(1)-N(1) are 89.96(17), 91.56(15) and 92.23(14)°, respectively, further indicate slight distortion of the octahedron.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The adjacent cobalt atoms, separated by 16.191 Å, are connected through <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bpfp ligands to form [Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpfp)] chains. These chains arrange in parallel fashion in a pseudo sheet and then stack on top of each other along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis with a rotation (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>). It is interesting that these 1D chains in the consecutive sheets can directly complete a high dimensional supramolecular through O<ce:inf loc="post">H2O</ce:inf>–H⋯O<ce:inf loc="post">bpfp</ce:inf> hydrogen bonds (O⋯O 2.697 Å, 154.0°), as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. Also, the nitrate anions of crystallization are involved into O<ce:inf loc="post">H2O</ce:inf>–H⋯O<ce:inf loc="post">NO3</ce:inf>- hydrogen bonding with coordinated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (O⋯O 2.719 Å, 167.3°). The strong O–H⋯O hydrogen bonds, which play main function in packing the whole crystal structure, are found in many Co-containing compounds, such as [Co(4,4<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bpy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
 and [Co(dcbp)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bcbp=4,4<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-dicarboxy-2,2<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bipyridine) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The adjacent cobalt atoms, separated by 16.191 Å, are connected through μ 2-bpfp ligands to form [Co(H2O)2(CH3OH)2(4-bpfp)] chains. These chains arrange in parallel fashion in a pseudo sheet and then stack on top of each other along the c-axis with a rotation ( ). It is interesting that these 1D chains in the consecutive sheets can directly complete a high dimensional supramolecular through OH2O-H⋯Obpfp hydrogen bonds (O⋯O 2.697 Å, 154.0°), as shown in  . Also, the nitrate anions of crystallization are involved into OH2O-H⋯ONO3- hydrogen bonding with coordinated H2O (O⋯O 2.719 Å, 167.3°). The strong O-H⋯O hydrogen bonds, which play main function in packing the whole crystal structure, are found in many Co-containing compounds, such as [Co(4,4'-bpy)(H2O)4] n   and [Co(dcbp)(H2O)2]H2O (H2bcbp=4,4'-dicarboxy-2,2'-bipyridine) .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystal structure of [Co(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(3-bpfp)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The molecular structure and atom-labeling scheme of polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor>. The local coordination environment of the central Co(II) ion can be described as a slightly distorted octahedron completed by methanol molecule, isothiocyanate group and bridging 3-bpfp ligand. It is noted that the bond lengths of Co–N<ce:inf loc="post">bpfp</ce:inf> (2.157(4) Å) and Co–O<ce:inf loc="post">CH3OH</ce:inf> (2.148(3) Å) are longer than the corresponding bond lengths in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. This is mainly attributed to the influence of the coordinated isothiocyanate groups. Isothiocyanate group is often employed in the researches of coordination polymers. It adopts the terminal mode in most reported polymeric structures , the end-to-end bridging mode is less reported . In polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, isothiocyanate group adopts the terminal mode and is almost linear with an N–C–S angle of 179.2(5), while the connection between Co atom and NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> group is bent with an angle of 160.0(4)°.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of [Co(NCS)2(CH3OH)2(3-bpfp)] n  (2)

The molecular structure and atom-labeling scheme of polymer 2 are given in  . The local coordination environment of the central Co(II) ion can be described as a slightly distorted octahedron completed by methanol molecule, isothiocyanate group and bridging 3-bpfp ligand. It is noted that the bond lengths of Co-Nbpfp (2.157(4) Å) and Co-OCH3OH (2.148(3) Å) are longer than the corresponding bond lengths in 1. This is mainly attributed to the influence of the coordinated isothiocyanate groups. Isothiocyanate group is often employed in the researches of coordination polymers. It adopts the terminal mode in most reported polymeric structures , the end-to-end bridging mode is less reported . In polymer 2, isothiocyanate group adopts the terminal mode and is almost linear with an N-C-S angle of 179.2(5), while the connection between Co atom and NCS- group is bent with an angle of 160.0(4)°.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG5"></ce:float-anchor>, each 3-bpfp adopts the bis(monodentate) bridging coordination mode and connects neighboring Co(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> fragments into 1D wave-like chains. While, the intra-chain distance (15.550 Å) between the neighboring Co(II) ions is shorter than that of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which is also due to the influence of NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> groups. The double S<ce:inf loc="post">NCS</ce:inf>⋯H–O<ce:inf loc="post">CH3OH</ce:inf> hydrogen bonds (S⋯O 3.243 Å, 130.4°) link the adjacent chains giving a novel 2D network in <ce:italic>ac</ce:italic> plane. Although these S⋯H–O hydrogen bonds are not strong, the existences of them are crucial for the surpramolecular structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In  , each 3-bpfp adopts the bis(monodentate) bridging coordination mode and connects neighboring Co(NCS)2(CH3OH)2 fragments into 1D wave-like chains. While, the intra-chain distance (15.550 Å) between the neighboring Co(II) ions is shorter than that of polymer 1, which is also due to the influence of NCS- groups. The double SNCS⋯H-OCH3OH hydrogen bonds (S⋯O 3.243 Å, 130.4°) link the adjacent chains giving a novel 2D network in ac plane. Although these S⋯H-O hydrogen bonds are not strong, the existences of them are crucial for the surpramolecular structure.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Thermal investigation</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The TG curve of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows it loses weight from 87 to 148 °C corresponding to the release of coordinated water and methanol molecule, then loses weight from 170 to 414 °C corresponding to the decomposition of 4-bpfp ligand and nitrate anion; the residue is Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>. A plateau region is observed from 414 to 900 °C, followed by decomposition of Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> into CoO until 918 °C. Accompanying these processes there are two endothermic and two exothermic effects on the DTA curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows similar behavior as <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> upon heating, except that in the TG curve of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> the weight losses in the ranges of 48–150, 291–775 and 900–918 °C correspond to the release of methanol molecule, the decomposition of 3-bpfp ligand, NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> group and Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>. The final residue is CoO. The observed TG results of polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are in good agreement with the calculated values.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal investigation

The TG curve of polymer 1 shows it loses weight from 87 to 148 °C corresponding to the release of coordinated water and methanol molecule, then loses weight from 170 to 414 °C corresponding to the decomposition of 4-bpfp ligand and nitrate anion; the residue is Co2O3. A plateau region is observed from 414 to 900 °C, followed by decomposition of Co2O3 into CoO until 918 °C. Accompanying these processes there are two endothermic and two exothermic effects on the DTA curve of 1. Polymer 2 shows similar behavior as 1 upon heating, except that in the TG curve of 2 the weight losses in the ranges of 48-150, 291-775 and 900-918 °C correspond to the release of methanol molecule, the decomposition of 3-bpfp ligand, NCS- group and Co2O3. The final residue is CoO. The observed TG results of polymers 1 and 2 are in good agreement with the calculated values.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Third-order nonlinear optical properties</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The UV–Vis absorption spectra for the two investigated polymers were obtained in dilute solutions of DMF. Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> display strong absorption peaks in 283 and 278 nm, respectively, and have relatively weak linear absorption ranging from 350 to 1000 nm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Third-order nonlinear optical properties

The UV-Vis absorption spectra for the two investigated polymers were obtained in dilute solutions of DMF. Polymer 1 and 2 display strong absorption peaks in 283 and 278 nm, respectively, and have relatively weak linear absorption ranging from 350 to 1000 nm.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">We study the third-order NLO properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in DMF solutions using the <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan technique. The NLO absorption components were evaluated by <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan experiment under an open aperture configuration. The NLO refractive properties were assessed by dividing the normalized <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan data obtained under the closed aperture configuration by the normalized <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan data obtained under the open aperture configuration. A reasonably good fit between the experimental data and the theoretical curve suggests that the experimentally obtained NLO effects are effectively third order in nature. In

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In principle, compared with traditional NLO material, the incorporation of metal atoms in coordination polymers introduce more sublevels into the energy hierarchy, which permits more allowed electronic transition to take place and hence larger NLO effect . Meanwhile, the strength of NLO properties can be altered by the π back-donation capacity of metal ions to ligands . Therefore, due to the strong π back-donation capacity of Co(II) ion, Co(II) coordination polymers usually exhibit strong NLO properties, such as [Co(bpms)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (bpms=1,2-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)disulfenyl), [Co(bbbt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (bbbt=1,1<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole) , as well as polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. In addition, the similarity in the structures of the two polymers also leads to similar NLO properties. This is consistent with the case that the structural types of coordination polymer also have important influence on the NLO properties .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In principle, compared with traditional NLO material, the incorporation of metal atoms in coordination polymers introduce more sublevels into the energy hierarchy, which permits more allowed electronic transition to take place and hence larger NLO effect . Meanwhile, the strength of NLO properties can be altered by the π back-donation capacity of metal ions to ligands . Therefore, due to the strong π back-donation capacity of Co(II) ion, Co(II) coordination polymers usually exhibit strong NLO properties, such as [Co(bpms)2(NCS)2] n  (bpms=1,2-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)disulfenyl), [Co(bbbt)2(NCS)2] n  (bbbt=1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole) , as well as polymers 1 and 2. In addition, the similarity in the structures of the two polymers also leads to similar NLO properties. This is consistent with the case that the structural types of coordination polymer also have important influence on the NLO properties .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In summary, we have demonstrated the syntheses, crystal structures and NLO properties of two new 1D Co(II) coordination polymers. The study of third-order NLO properties reveals that the two polymers exhibit similar nonlinear absorption and self-focusing behaviors in DMF solution. We further testify that the structural types of coordination polymer have important influence on the NLO properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have demonstrated the syntheses, crystal structures and NLO properties of two new 1D Co(II) coordination polymers. The study of third-order NLO properties reveals that the two polymers exhibit similar nonlinear absorption and self-focusing behaviors in DMF solution. We further testify that the structural types of coordination polymer have important influence on the NLO properties.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of polymer {[Co(H2O)2(CH3OH)2(4-bpfp)](NO3)2} n  (1)

A clear methanol solution (5 ml) of 4-bpfp (59.2 mg, 0.20 mmol) was dropwise added into a methanol solution (3 ml) of Co(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) at room temperature. The vial was subjected to shaking about 30 min resulting in a pale red solution. On standing for three weeks, pale red crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained in 46% yield. Anal. Calc. for C20H28N4O12Co: C, 33.34; H, 4.87; N, 12.50%; Found: C, 33.52; H, 4.77; N, 12.83%. IR (KBr) ν(cm-1): 3363s, 1621s, 1492m, 1468m, 1384s, 1283m, 1162w, 1006m, 831w, 744w, 708w.

Preparation of polymer [Co(NCS)2(CH3OH)2(3-bpfp)] n  (2)

At room temperature, a clear methanol solution (4 ml) of 3-bpfp (59.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) was slowly added into a methanol solution (2 ml) of Co(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) with continuous stirring. Then a methanol solution (2 ml) of KSCN (19.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) was dropwise added into above mixture while stirring and resulted in a clear red solution. In the next day, pale red crystals (yield: 43%) were deposited from the solution. Anal. Calc. for C20H22CoN6O4S2: C, 39.93; H, 4.55; N, 14.71; Found: C, 39.47; H, 4.50; N, 14.78%. IR (KBr) ν(cm-1): 3290m, 2089s, 1634s, 1600m, 1460w, 1437s, 1274m, 1159w, 1008s, 823w, 735m, 709w.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Two novel Co(II) coordination polymers {[Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4-bpfp)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (4-bpfp=<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine) and [Co(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(3-bpfp)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (3-bpfp=<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bis(3-pyridylformyl)piperazine) have been synthesized and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Both the polymers consist of one-dimensional chains constructed by bridging bpfp ligands and Co(II) ions. The existence of O⋯H–O hydrogen bond in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and S⋯H–O hydrogen bond in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> play important roles in creating interesting supramolecular structures. Their third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties in DMF solution have been studied by <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>-scan technique. The results reveal that polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit strong NLO absorption effects (<ce:italic>α</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>=9.00×10<ce:sup loc="post">−11</ce:sup> m W<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; 1.41<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−10</ce:sup> m W<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and self-focusing performance (<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>=3.24×10<ce:sup loc="post">−16</ce:sup> esu for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; 3.05<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−16</ce:sup> esu for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) in DMF solutions. The corresponding effective NLO susceptibilities <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">(3)</ce:sup> values are 3.08<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−12</ce:sup> esu (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and 4.70<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−12</ce:sup> esu (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). All of the values are comparable to those of the reported good NLO materials. Additionally, the TG-DTA results of the two polymers are in agreement with the crystal structures.</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Thermal investigation</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The TG curve of polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows it loses weight from 87 to 148 °C corresponding to the release of coordinated water and methanol molecule, then loses weight from 170 to 414 °C corresponding to the decomposition of 4-bpfp ligand and nitrate anion; the residue is Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>. A plateau region is observed from 414 to 900 °C, followed by decomposition of Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> into CoO until 918 °C. Accompanying these processes there are two endothermic and two exothermic effects on the DTA curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows similar behavior as <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> upon heating, except that in the TG curve of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> the weight losses in the ranges of 48–150, 291–775 and 900–918 °C correspond to the release of methanol molecule, the decomposition of 3-bpfp ligand, NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> group and Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>. The final residue is CoO. The observed TG results of polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are in good agreement with the calculated values.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Third-order nonlinear optical properties</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The UV–Vis absorption spectra for the two investigated polymers were obtained in dilute solutions of DMF. Polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> display strong absorption peaks in 283 and 278 nm, respectively, and have relatively weak linear absorption ranging from 350 to 1000 nm.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The non-linear absorptive properties of polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are depicted in . The NLO absorption performance can be well presented by the following Eqs. :<display>
<formula id="FD1">
<ce:label>(1)</ce:label>

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two novel Co(II) coordination polymers {[Co(H2O)2(CH3OH)2(4-bpfp)](NO3)2} n  1 (4-bpfp=N,N '-bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine) and [Co(NCS)2(CH3OH)2(3-bpfp)] n  2 (3-bpfp=N,N '-bis(3-pyridylformyl)piperazine) have been synthesized and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Both the polymers consist of one-dimensional chains constructed by bridging bpfp ligands and Co(II) ions. The existence of O⋯H-O hydrogen bond in 1 and S⋯H-O hydrogen bond in 2 play important roles in creating interesting supramolecular structures. Their third-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties in DMF solution have been studied by Z-scan technique. The results reveal that polymers 1 and 2 exhibit strong NLO absorption effects (α 2=9.00×10-11 m W-1 for 1; 1.41×10-10 m W-1 for 2) and self-focusing performance (n 2=3.24×10-16 esu for 1; 3.05×10-16 esu for 2) in DMF solutions. The corresponding effective NLO susceptibilities χ (3) values are 3.08×10-12 esu (1) and 4.70×10-12 esu (2). All of the values are comparable to those of the reported good NLO materials. Additionally, the TG-DTA results of the two polymers are in agreement with the crystal structures.

Thermal investigation

The TG curve of polymer 1 shows it loses weight from 87 to 148 °C corresponding to the release of coordinated water and methanol molecule, then loses weight from 170 to 414 °C corresponding to the decomposition of 4-bpfp ligand and nitrate anion; the residue is Co2O3. A plateau region is observed from 414 to 900 °C, followed by decomposition of Co2O3 into CoO until 918 °C. Accompanying these processes there are two endothermic and two exothermic effects on the DTA curve of 1. Polymer 2 shows similar behavior as 1 upon heating, except that in the TG curve of 2 the weight losses in the ranges of 48-150, 291-775 and 900-918 °C correspond to the release of methanol molecule, the decomposition of 3-bpfp ligand, NCS- group and Co2O3. The final residue is CoO. The observed TG results of polymers 1 and 2 are in good agreement with the calculated values.

Third-order nonlinear optical properties

The UV-Vis absorption spectra for the two investigated polymers were obtained in dilute solutions of DMF. Polymer 1 and 2 display strong absorption peaks in 283 and 278 nm, respectively, and have relatively weak linear absorption ranging from 350 to 1000 nm.

The non-linear absorptive properties of polymers 1 and 2 are depicted in . The NLO absorption performance can be well presented by the following Eqs. :  (1) T(Z)= 1    π  q(Z) ∫-∞ +∞ ln[1+q(Z)]e τ2  dτ,     (2) q(Z)=∫0 ∞∫0 ∞α2  I0  1+(Z/Z0)2   e [-2(γ/ω0)2-(t/t0)2]  1-e -α0L  α0  r dr dt,  where T(z) represents the transmittance which is defined here as the ratio of the transmitted pulse energy and the incident pulse energy at 532 nm; I(z) is the incident light irradiance; I 0 is the peak irradiation intensity at focus (I 0=8.2×108 W cm-2); ω 0 is the spot radius of the laser beam at focus; α 0 and α 2 denote the linear and non-linear absorption coefficients, respectively; L is the optical path (L=0.5 cm in the current experiments); r is the radial coordinate; τ is the time; t 0 is the pulse width. As shown in , the absorptions increase as the incident light irradiance rises. The normalized transmittance (T) drops to about 82% for polymer 1 and 71% for polymer 2 at the focus, both of which show strong NLO absorptive effects. The best fits of Eq.  to the open-aperture configuration of , give the effective α 2 values of 9.00×10-11 m W-1 (1) and 1.4×10-10 (2), respectively.

The non-linear refractive properties of polymers 1 and 2 are depicted in . The valley/peak pattern of the normalized transmittance curves show that both polymers have the positive signs for the refractive non-linearity, which give rise to self-focusing behavior. The third-order NLO refractive index n 2 of the polymers can be derived by Eqs. :  (3) T(Z,S)= ∫-∞ +∞ε0cn0 π∫0 r  E a (r,t,z)  2r dr dt S∫-∞ +∞  I0 πω0 2  2  e -(t/t0)2 dt  ,     (4) E a (r,t,z)= 2π   iλ(l-z)  e [iπr2/λ(l-z)]∫0 ∞E(r',t,z)J0  2πr'r λ(l-z)  e [iπr'/λ(l-z)]r' dr,     (5) E(r',t,z)=2   I(r',t,z) ε0cn0     e {(kn2/α2)ln[1+q(r',t,z)]},  where Z is the distance of the sample from the focal point; l is the distance between the aperture and focus; ε 0 and c are the permittivity and speed of light in vacuum; n 0 and n 2 are the linear and nonlinear refractive indices of the sample, respectively; S=1-exp[-2(r a/ω a)2] is the linear aperture transmittance. According to Eqs. , the refractive index n 2 are calculated to be 3.2×10-16 esu for 1 and 3.0×10-16 esu for 2.

The χ (3) values were calculated to be 3.08×10-12 esu for 1 and 4.70×10-12 esu for 2, both of which can compared to some reported clusters, such as [MOS3Cu3(4-pic)6]⋅Br (M=Mo, W; 4'-pic=4-picoline) (5.4×10-12 and 5.5×10-12 esu) .
